title: MendelMax 3 Z axis Magnetic Isolators New Version

description.text: These are experimental isolators that I created that utilize neodymium magnets to hold together. They will hold the couplers together while printing but release in the case of a bed crash. The magnets are 1/4" diameter by 3/8" length and should simply press in place. Link to video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ag9MiQwUcZs Edit 9/9/15: I have added a v2 that I think works better for eliminating Z axis wobble. Still utilize the same magnets as before. Update: I think I may like the original over the v2 parts. The v2 parts seem to have more play than I would like.

Any resolution, 3-4 shells and 30% infill is what I would recommend.  
Press in the magnets. Mine pressed in nicely. 
Install and print.

description.text: 8mm nut output from Giles Bathgate OpenScad Metric Fastners http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Libraries#Metric_Fastners_by_Giles_Bathgate . It has been trimmed back to work as a Jam Nut basically backing up your 8mm (or 5/16 imperial) to a work similar to a nylon insert lock nut. or you can just use it instead of a real nut in non-critical applications.

output .stl for any nut from an OpenScad library, center (rotate if need be) and place on your build plate in Replicator G. you can go back into skeinforge and duplicate/array to fill up your build platform if you need a large number of nuts. use the difference command in OpenScad to adjust your nut size to create the thinner Jam nuts. (see http://www.boltdepot.com/fastener-information/Nuts-Washers/Metric-Nut-Size.aspx for sizes).
If you really want to do it right adjust your inner diameter and run a thread cutting tool inside of your nut some to get the threads started (but not completely).

title: 25mm fan mount for a dual extruding Rostock Max

description.text: I don't know if this is useful for other printers or not, but I made it to go on the dual extruder mount that I had previously downloaded and printed for my Rostock Max. It holds a 25mm fan, but needs a shim on the side to hold it in place quietly. I was lucky enough to be able to print this in ABS on a cold bed with the help of extra hold hair spray. This is based on https://github.com/seemecnc/RostockMAX/blob/master/PRINTED_ADDONS/70766%2025mm%20fan%20shroud.STL

Print this out and snap it onto the aluminum spacers that come with the Rostock Max. You will see in the pictures how I have my extruders set up. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243270 as the dual extruder mount. You may need to file a little bit of plastic off of some corners if it interferes with the delta arm movement or does not want to fit between your dual extruder mount and your effector. If necessary, unmount the dual extruder mount from the effector or loosen screws. You should probably print this with a brim.

comments.text: Which Duel Extruder is that? did you find it on thingiverse? What control software are you using?
comments.author: HerrVan

comments.text: I am not exactly sure what you are asking, so I will toss out a bunch of information and hope that helps. The hotends are the SeeMeCNC hotends. The dual extruder mount is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243270. My firmware is Repetier. I was using Octroprint to send the gcode to the printer. I am not sure why the control software matters though.
comments.author: HerrVan

author: nathanstenzel

description.text:
The Raptor Reloaded is an updated release of the original that incorporates feedback from the e-NABLE community and has CAD design source files available in STEP, IGES, IPT, and F3D formats. Updates in the 12-17-14 release include:
-- Improved print-ability due to custom modeled supports
-- Cyborg Beast compatible sizing
-- Improved dovetail geometry
-- New tensioner retention clip
-- Easier to use tensioner pins
-- Low profile elastics with two tie-off options
-- More access to elastic and flexsor routing channels
-- Debossed versioning information on palm and gauntlet
-- Slimmer, more anthropomorhpic fingers
-- Narrower knuckle block
-- More intuitive assembly (new one-way proximals)
-- Thorough documentation and modular design
-- Source files in native Fusion 360 format, also STEP and IGES
-- Additional velcro-mounting options as well as traditional velcro loop and leather options
-- Re-oriented snap-pin head recesses to improve printability
-- Knuckle pins are now removable, making the hand easy to repair and upgrade
-- Strengthened tie-bars on finger tips Native CAD source files available here:
Full Assembly
Left Palm
Right Palm
Gauntlet
Proximal Phalange
Fingertip
Finger Snap Pin Detailed assembly instructions available here. Changelog:
-- 1/4/15 -- updated finger snap pins (raptor_2.0_finger_pin.stl) to fix fit problems. Updated full hand plates with new pin as well. AB
-- 2/1/15 -- updated cover image to reflect recommended elastic stringing, added fingertip with finger nail that can be painted, added link to detailed print and assembly instructions on Instructables. AB

Detailed assembly instructions available here. For a complete hand, you will need to print the following:
-- 1x raptor_reloaded_left_palm_supported.stl or raptor_reloaded_right_palm_supported.stl
-- 2x raptor_reloaded_knuckle_pin.stl
-- 1x raptor_reloaded_thumb_pin.stl
-- 5x raptor_2.0_proximal.stl
-- 5x raptor_2.0_finger_pin.stl
-- 5x raptor_2.0_fingertip.stl
-- 1x raptor_reloaded_gauntlet_supported.stl
-- 2x raptor_reloaded_wirst_pin.stl
-- 2x raptor_reloaded_wrist_pin_cap.stl
-- 1x raptor_reloaded_tensioner.stl
-- 1xraptor_reloaded_retention_clip.stl
-- 5x raptor_reloaded_tensioner_pin.stl Assembling a Raptor Hand requires the following materials:
(4 feet) Velcro, double-sided (2” wide)
(8 feet) Non-elastic nylon cord, 0.9mm
(5 feet) Flexible elastic cord
(5) Tensioner screws
(3) Palm velcro attachment screws with stop nuts
(12 inches) Firm Foam Padding (5 ¾” wide)
(5) Lee Tippi Micro Gel Fingertip Grips (optional) All of the parts needed for assembly can be found easily in most areas, but if you prefer to get everything in one place, 3D Universe offers kits with all of the assembly materials needed for producing a Raptor Hand: http://shop3duniverse.com/collections/3d-printable-kits/products/raptor-hand-by-e-nable-assembly-materials-kit

comments.text: Shouldn't one digit that will be used as the thumb be unscaled? The thumb knuckle insertion space on the palm will not be widened when the palm part is widened, because it opens perpendicular to the other knuckle joints. I printed the whole set at 125% scale (expanded across the palm only) and found that a widened knuckle doesn't fit on the thumb socket. Similarly, as for the pin for the thumb knuckle, isn't it the only knuckle pin  that should not be made longer?
comments.author: damauk

comments.text: The intent is to scale the parts uniformly in each axis direction (X,Y,Z). The width of the palm is just used to determine the general scale. This method actually works surprisingly well, I have made hands at 120% scale and 205% and each one fit the recipient. Hopefully this clears up the confusion.

title: Apple IIc Raspberry Pi case - Model A+

description.text: A case for the Raspberry Pi Model A+ in the style of an Apple IIc (or, if you prefer, the Apple //c). I took some liberties with the IIc design to accommodate the Pi, but still keeping as close to the original as possible. The floppy drive latch and handle both articulate, though the handle doesn't rotate completely, lest it interfere with the HDMI port. Prints available at Shapeways.com: https://www.shapeways.com/model/2875436/apple-iic-raspberry-pi-model-a-case.html Available finished, painted and assembled from my etsy shop: https://www.etsy.com/listing/215587376/apple-iic-raspberry-pi-case

author: option8

description.text: A solution for refilling Zim filament spools. Zim uses a proprietary filament cartridge system. Popping open the case reveals the filament spool. Squeezing the sides of this spool allows the top to be removed. These sprockets can be attached to either side, with the hex shaft going to a drill, and the other held in the free hand. Insert the new filament in the hole at the base of the spool and rewind the spool. Be sure not to lose the little black o-ring that fits in the groove in the neck of the cartridge.

(edited 15-03-02) First of all, be sure to check out: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:700346 this links you to the newer version made with a joystick module that is very much available and inexpensive. Now, back to the original description: Here's one that almost no one needs, but I did, so I designed this thing. It's just a housing for the out-of-production Electronic Brick Joystick breakout board. It's a Playstation2 style analog joystick that is easy to use with Arduino and two analog inputs. The button also clicks for a momentary switch. I looked around and couldn't find a supply for these boards anymore, but hey, if you have one in a drawer like I did, you might want to put it in this box. Here's the link to the "discontinued" page: http://www.trossenrobotics.com/store/p/6340-Electronic-Brick-Playstation2-Analog-Joystick.aspx Cheers.

This is a print of the San Francisco bay area I made based on the fantastic tool by Thatcher Chamberlin, Terrain2STL. For a detailed overview of how I created it, check my blog pose here. Check out the article on it at 3dPrint.com.

Printed on my Makerbot Replicator 1 (Sailfish firmware) with these settings:
  • First layers (water) translucent "Neon Blue" PLA, all later layers (ground) light gray PLA. No raft, no supports.
  • Extruded @ 230 degs, HBP off.
  • 2 shells, 10% infill, 200 micron.
  • Print speed 120mm/sec, travel 150mm/sec.
  • Each print took anywhere from 2.5-3.5 hours.

author: Tod0

title: Z-axis Makerbot-style endstop holder for Prusa i3 variants

description.text:
This is a remix of thing #64254 by Stefaan Ponnet. I simply changed the way the endstop is attached to fit Makerbot-style mechanical endstops. These endstops have the advantage of having an LED clearly showing the state of the switch which I find helpful when calibrating the Z-axis home position and leveling the heatbed.  
The holder is clipped onto the Z-axis 8mm smooth rod on the motor side. This design can be used with just about any Prusa i3 variant, including the P3Steel as shown.  
OpenSCAD sources (with proper attribution to Stefaan) are included so the thing can be further remixed.
Printed in PLA with 35% infill. Requires 1 x 20mm M3 bolt and nut for attaching to the smooth rod. Requires 2 x 8mm M3 bolts and nuts for attaching the Makerbot-style mechanical endstop PCB.

comments.text: Also great for the Y-axis endstop, activated by the bearing holder under the Y-axis chassis.

I created this model to speed up how I go about calibrating my Thing-O-Matic and associated skeinforge settings. It consists of the following parts:

  • One comb-shaped structure aligned on the X axis with teeth spaced 0.1mm to 1.0mm apart in 0.1mm increments.

  • One comb-shaped structure aligned on the Y axis with teeth spaced 0.1mm to 1.0mm apart in 0.1mm increments.

  • One short square for checking fill algorithms.

  • One 608 bearing scale ring (OD: 22mm, ID:8mm, Height: 7mm) for checking inner hole diameter.
    • Source is maintained at https://github.com/clothbot/makerbot/blob/master/tests/thingomatic/spaces/test_spaces.scad

• Download the test_spaces.stl

  • Slice in skeinforge (or your favorite slicing software)

  • Print.

  • Eyeball comb spacing, fill square and measure 608 bearing blank.

  • Check the comb-shaped structures for signs of skipped steps, backlash and other qualitative metrics.

  • When printing raftless, check the bottoms of the comb teeth for too much, too little, or poorly spaced first layers.

  • Count back from the largest comb tooth spacing (1.0mm down to 0.1mm) to figure out the minimum spacing needed between objects for them to print separately. With fill I can only get down to about 0.5mm; without fill all the teeth are separate but I land up printing a springy part instead of something rigid.

  • Adjust a slicing and/or machine parameter(s).

  • Repeat 2-5.
    • Variations:
  • For faster iteration, download the OpenSCAD file and delete off all except one or both the comb structures.

title: RUMBA Electronic mount for K250 from Ultibots

description.text:
Update:
2014-12-18: V4: board turned around -> screw connectors more room, board re-measured
2014-12-17: no support, deeper plate This is a re-work of my initial electronic mount for the K250 from Ultibots. The original one by Ultibots is well designed but stabs into the stand of the K250 not leaving room for other mounts. The picture is near final - one mount was still at the wrong place. This one is for the RUMBA board, a version for RAMPS is available, too.
Check the G-code that it is complete till the top of the print. setting $fn to high values increases the size of the STL file till slic3r can't slice it anymore.

I made this as a gift for my wife.  It turned out great and looks amazing in the dark!

This ornament was designed around the BlinkM MinM Smart LED. I went with a Winter theme and scene, utilizing the LED to really bring it together. The BlinkM is programable, hence the color change and accepts a wide range of low voltages, thus perfect for li-ion power. Warning, the BlinkM will not stop pulling power from the li-ion cell at 2.7 volts. I recommend a li-ion cell with integrated over discharge protection. I have no idea regarding runtime but it has been going strong off and on now for a few months. I really enjoyed making this thing and I hope you do too.

  • Print and clean case (Ornament Case.skp) and lid (Ornament Lid Only.skp). I painted both these pieces bone to give the appearance of painted wood.

  • Cut and glue paper to lid. In my Winter design, I printed the message and some accompanying graphics with an inkjet printer. I even poked holes in the paper to simulate snow. Note, the light will appear brightest at the top right corner of the ornament.

  • Design, buy, create, add, etc., your message and any desired props using super glue. I printed three trees, adding a distanced effect and a star (Ornament Lid Complete.skp). The star was mounted so that it would sit directly in front of the LED and be thus illuminated. I painted the trees green, dusted them with artificial modelers snow and left the star ABS natural because it just looked right.

  • Insert rocker switch. Careful not to crack the case, it may be tight.

  • Drill small tap holes for screws and mount battery case.

  • Mount smart LED. I used a few breadboard headers recessed into the plastic, but I imagine a drop of hot glue would have done the trick.

  • Solder connections.

  • Add battery and check height for lid closure.

  • Drill (if necessary) and add small magnets to the corners of the case and lid. Make sure you have the magnets facing to attract and not repel (Yes, I made this mistake and it sucked).

  • Fire it up. Receive adoration.
    • Ingredients:
    A. BlinkM MinM Smart LED.
    B. CR123 or RCR123 Battery Holder ... with two screws.
    C. CR123 or RCR123.
    D. Rectangle Rocker Switch ... old computer power supply style.
    E. Eight Small Magnets.
    F. Imagination ... which you have or you wouldn't be browsing Thingiverse. Happy Printing. ~ GearsOfWow

Greatest punk band in Houston!

Start a new project merging several skills in one task. This is my tank track robot controlled by a Raspberry Pi using a webservice. You can control the robot over dynamic website with webcam view. The RSPI also provides RPI-Wireless-Hotspot, so it is possible to connect directly with your smartphone.
An Arduino-Micro communicates to the RSPI over I2C and controls 8 servos. Also a battery state monitor is implemented. I decide to use standard AA Accus for powering with 2 rows a 5x 1,2 volt. A step-up/ step-down switching voltage regulator guaranteed 5 volt supply despite low battery.
See latest video on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D2brukbh378 Updates:
01/04/16: After a long break, I return to the project again. The Raspberry Pi 3B has now integrated Bluetooth and FiFi which means it has more performance and i can remove the "Ampere-eating" WiFi-Stick. Also checking the use of adressable digital servos or selfmade Digital2PWM-Adaptor for serial (BUS) connection. My intention is reducing the amount of cable to the arm. 07/07/15: Project goes on. Currently, the main problem is the power, respectively the duration of the battery power supply. 1 camera, 8 servos, 2 controller, web service, and Wi-Fi hotspot consume a total of 2.5 amperes. Maybe I wanted to solve too much at once :-((
My aim is: Remote-controlled robot with camera. Looking for an alternative video transmission system without web service 02/26/15: Add Tank-Track for 1.75mm Filament rod. 02/05/15: Software implemented. RSP used as WLAN Hotspot with Webserver -> communicates to Arduino over serial - Arduino over I2C to PCA9685. RSPI won't work in Multislave I2C Mode :-(( 01/21/15: Fault in the electrical circuit improved. MOSFET got too little voltage on UGS -> reduced resistance 01/20/15: Build new Battery-Pack for more current available. Using 16 x AA á 6V (4 x 4 pack) 01/19/15: Implements PCA9685. Works fine! First trial without RSP for verfication of trigonometric calculation on Arduino. 01/08/15: First trial completed. Built a experimental arrangement with a old joystick and a second Arduino-Micro which simulates the RSPI-I2C communication (see image). ARGHH! Huge twitching of the servos because Arduino is overloaded with I2C and 8 servos! Special servo driver ordered (Adafruits-PCA9685) to save Arduino-Performance. 01/06/15: Add layout extension board preview. Not checked if all works - release of eagle file after validation by function. 12/28/14: Laser pointer moved to the middle of the gripper - now i can point to the thing i want to grip exactly.
-Change cam to a RSPI-Wide-Angle Cam. In fact this camera is much lighter than the first one!
-Change arm wiring! Because of problems with bending and buckling the wires between the servos i decide to route them on the side which made it necessary to implement the cam to the other side. So add 2 additional cable guides. (see new images) 12/21/14: The chassis is wide enough now.It is not necessary to desolder the cinch video connector. This is a work-in-progress project and wil bee updated regularly ;-)

author: rickdegreef

description.text:
I finally finished printing the Unicorn.  I really wish I had gone for the two piece derivative, it would've been way easier to finish and attach everything!
I used the printable linear slide.  It works so-so, but has a good amount of stiction... as do the rotary joints on the servo connectors... so I wrote up this quick sketch to let me run a burn-in test on the unicorn and try to loosen up the joints.
The goal of this is to allow you to test your unicorn WITHOUT an Extruder Controller.  However, if you're comfortable re-flashing your EC, you can load it with the Arduino Bootloader and use it instead of an Arduino.  I hope the D9 port on the extruder is the same as pin 9 in Arduino - if so, it should work with the EC hooked up according to the usual instructions.  Caveat Emptor; you'll have to re-flash your EC back to the reprap / makerbot software when done, and don't come crying to me if you have to get some funky ISP programmer or it doesn't work for you or you brick your EC and Makerbot has a two month backlog on them... 
The current delay for a pen move is 1 second.  This seems pretty good, with a small pause at the top and bottom of each move.

Tested! Works! Bugs fixed! Updated Instructions to include unicron calibration! Pictures of hookup coming soon! I use the Arduino Mini Pro for most of my development - its tiny and looks awesome in your projects... but any Arduino should be able to run this code. I generally solder the mini pro with male pins. Below are the hookup instructions for that. If you want to use Female Headers or a regular Arduino, the instructions are the same, just skip the mini breadboard and jumper the servo straight to the arduino. Assumes you already have the Arduino software installed.

  • Attach Arduino Mini Pro to mini breadboard.

  • Use jumper wires to attach the servo connector to the mini pro via the following pins:
    Gnd -> Black wire
    Vcc -> Red wire
    9 -> Yellow wire

  • Connect your FTDI cable (yes, the same one you use on your makerbot... or a spare) to the Arduino Mini Pro

  • Open Arduino on your computer, load the UnicornTester.pde sketch, and Compile, then Upload to I/O board. If you have any issues, make sure your serial port is configured and try again.

  • Open the Serial Monitor (right-most button on the button bar, Ctrl-Shift-M, or Tools -> Serial Monitor under the menu)

  • Make sure the Baud Rate drop down reads 57,600, and your caps lock is off

  • Put your unicorn through a few manual cycles. Keep your finger on the reset button of the Arduino, ready to stop the test in case of issues
    a. Press "u" ENTER
    b. Observe as the unicorn lifts the pen carriage
    c. Press "d" ENTER
    d. Observe as the unicorn drops the pen carriage

  • At first, the motor was only moving the carriage a little - the "rotating joint" on the servo connector needs to have a lot of stiction in it to get good full strokes. I've considered just gluing it in position (with the servo down and the carriage at it's lowest possible point) but I think you want it to have some give in case of jams and for smooth linear motion... so I cranked down really good on the outer nut as follows:
    a. press "u" ENTER
    b. using pliers, grip the nut tightly
    c. press "d" ENTER (pause), release pliers
    d. press "u" ENTER (pause) "d" ENTER and check for good travel - repeat steps a-c until satisfied.

  • Once you can manually run the up and down commands with no sticking or issues and tightened the servo connector, proceed slowly through the remaining commands.
    a. Press "r" to move the unicorn up and down 10 times (20 seconds)
    b. Press "s" to move the unicorn up and down 100 times (3 minutes)
    c. Press "t" to move the unicorn up and down 1000 times (33 minutes)

  • To perform burn-in test, reset the arduino (to clear the Serial cache), and press "tt" for each hour of burn in you'd like to run. The Serial buffer on the arduino should hold the characters while each "t" is processed - this has a max of about 60 hours due to the size of the cache.
    • I did a 60 minute burn in and the motion seems very smooth now. Time to find something to print with my new Unicorn! I

author: celce

description.text:
This model is a Cleaning Challenge Device, to be used as a benchmark for evaluating the cleaning procedure for 3D printed objects.  
The Cleaning Challenge Device consists of a cylindrical base station with four holes, and four separate inserts. The inserts have a circular or square cross-section of varying diameter, which have been chosen to be both realistic for (industrial) printing and challenging for typical cleaning procedures. The distance that the inserts can be placed inside the holes is a measure of the cleaning efficacy, since any remaining dirt will prevent the inserts from sliding in completely.

Step 1: Print the base station and the four inserts, at highest resolution.
Step 2: Clean the base station and the four inserts using the regular post-processing cleaning procedures.
Step 3: Place the inserts into their respective holes in the base cylinder. Use the engravings to read out how many millimeter the inserts are able to move into the holes, which corresponds to the maximum depth that can be cleaned with your cleaning procedures.
The maximum depth is 10 mm.

author: Twiney

description.text:
The end stops for X and Y axis are difficult to adjust as they tend to get loose when unscrewed. The original two screw construction is complicated and I made this simpler "one screw" replacement for the axis.
There is no need for precise fine tuning of the X and Y end stops - I think this is a sufficient solution. The original M4 screws can be reused or be replaced by shorter ones.

title: WMD Nuke Chem Bio tokens / coins

description.text: Warning logos for Nuclear Chemical & Biological (NCB) as coins. You could also use them as ink stamps or other display options. See where I went next with this idea at https://www.shapeways.com/shops/fyrftd (tie bar/clasp & cufflinks! printable in varies metals or harder plastics)

using the graphic at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weapon_of_mass_destruction#mediaviewer/File:WMD_world_map.svg, I first removed the world map background in Visio. After some minor clean up, I exported a PNG file that I then turned to SVG via VectorMagic.com. I uploaded the SVG to AD's 123d application to give the 2D image 3D dimensions, and exported as an STL file.

title: Mendel Max cable clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yet more MendelMax cable clips for 20/20 Misumi-type aluminium extrusions based on Wilsons excellent original style.
Three sizes here and included is a plate of 8 small and 8 medium ones which are probably what you will be wanting if you are building a Mendel Max.
Following Wilsons original design they just clip on and can be (fairly) easily removed to add or alter wiring.
Also included are the HeeksCad files if you want to alter them further.

Print them out at 2 shells and 25-40% fill.
Clip them on and marvel at your sleek wiring loom.

Cute little Christmas Tree made out of 3 stacked diamonds. Scale to any size in your slicer and follow the instructions to print it to perfection. Want an original necklace for Christmas eve...drill out a hole in the top and pull a knotted thread through the top...BAM a stylish Christmas party!! Based on the graphic design of our own design Christmas cards for this year. For sale at http://www.en-designshop.com/products/diamond-tree-cards

A super easy and fast tree to print if you just use these settings Single wall print
Thickness: 0.8mm
Nozzle: 0.4mm
Fill: 0%
Temperature: 220
Speed: 30mm/s
Bottom/Top Thickness: 0mm
Use Spiral function if available Here is the trick to get a nice clean top of the tree.
Tweak settings for the last 10mm of your print: Speed 50% of original speed (15mm/s)
Lower the temp with 10 degrees to 210
decrease the flow by 10% to 90% of original flow If you don't alter these settings, most of the time the top of the tree will droop down/inside. Enjoy your print and merry Christmas!!

description.text: I have need to mount a motor to a shelf without using any fasteners. This thing is a notched sleeve that will fit a nema 17 motor snugly. Of course there's an OpenScad file, so you can size it to whatever you want. It fits nicely with any 'keyed' item of the same size. I am using it with this keyed shelf UClip: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5968 It works out fairly well, and the friction fit can be enhanced by fasteners or glue if you really need that. I did just create another motor mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5940 but that's the more typical faceplate with screws, and screws to attach variety. This one is all about not needing any fasteners.

1) Measure your motor. If it's not 42mm square (roughly nema 17), then change the OpenScad file to fit whatever size it is.
2) Print out the mount.
3) Slide it onto the keyed thing you want to attach it to
4) Slide the motor into the mount
5) Rejoice!

For your car or bike. No interior threads; the opening is tapered slightly so you should be able to get it to fit on most valve stems. Push it down and screw it on, the valve stem should cut its own threads.
Despite the fact that the measurements of the STL are indeed to proper scale, your printer may make the hole too small due to squeezing of the filament. You may need to scale it up a little bit for proper fit, as was the case with mine. If you like my designs, please consider Bitcoin donations: 1PyXaZGVyMXgAVC4xTPdu2wKwtZjGteudx

Print, screw on, enjoy.
If the default version is too small, try the _105 version.

description.text: Add on components for snap circuits kits. This should enable even more fun with the kiddies. Presently only a design for two connection components like resistors, speakers, motors, diodes etc. Others will follow. (Someday :)

• Print the part
  • Buy some mini Anorak snaps (Dritz 651601) and the assembly tool (Dritz 651600)
  • Solder your component to the inside of the flange of the long narrow snap part. (labeled "d" on the package.) Then do it again to the other side of the component, leaving enough room to stretch to each side of the part.
  • Solder the male snap "c" to the other side of the flange. Note: You may find it easier to do this after assembly. YMMV
  • Push both ends of the component into the printed part on the side with the recessed track.
  • Fit the corresponding tools into the tool holder.( "C" and "B")
  • Put a female snap "b" on the other side of the part.
  • Insert into the tool.
  • Tap with hammer to set the snap
  • Repeat on the other side

description.header: A gearbox designed around a large servo motor, a wormscrew gearbox with 13:1 gear ratio.
description.text:
The drive horns go through both sides of the gearbox.
The potentiometer is mounted to the gearbox indirectly using an involute gear.

UPDATE: Use the -1 files. They are newer and make screwing the gearbox together easier.

Requires:
  • 2x 30mm bearings (SKF 68062RS 30x42x7mm)
  • 1x 8mm bearing (SKF 608ZZ 8x22x7mm)
    • All parts can be printed at 0.3mm EXCEPT the gearboxscrew.stl 1) print
    2) assemble slice gearboxscrew.stl at 0.2mm or less. Print very slowly with a fan as this has lots of steep angles Servo modification:
    You will need to take the servo apart and modify it to allow continuous rotation
  • unscrew servo
  • remove motor board
  • remove potentiometer screw and potentiometer
  • under the main gear on top, remove the white plastic piece that the pot was pushed into.
  • Saw/cut the pillar of the main servo horn head
    • Assembly:
    All parts should go togther as per the exploded diagram.
    Once assembled, push the potentiometer through the hole in part "bottom plate pot holder"
    attach with a screw Special Mention:
    Although this gearbox was designed independatly of hairygael's "inmoov" gearbox design, there was a heavy dose of inspiration from the "inmoov" design. Once I saw that design, mine chaged slightly.

description.text:
Christmas greetings from the School of Architecture of Seville. This is a design made of wood MDF 3 mm thick over the skyline of Seville. It is one piece that is broken to ride a Christmas element with the star of Bethlehem.
Made by Quino Roncero and Juan Carlos González Pérez Juidias on an earlier design made for the FabLab Sevilla.
There has also been another design for gift over the skyline of Paris. This present is for students of French schools Sevilla who visited our fablab.

description.text:
Here is a first version of rolling mill for Kenwood.  
It is in several parts for better developments and easier printing.  
A ball bearing support plate is fixed on the main part which fits on the Kenwood.  
It is this plate which serves to support the two rolls.  
You can print a different plate to change the thickness but I work on the next version of adjustable.  
This is a M5 bolt stainless which rotates the roller.  
good print
